intro: Eugenia pipensis, commonly known as the Pichincha guava, is a small evergreen tree native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Myrtaceae family and is characterized by its glossy, lance-shaped leaves and fragrant white flowers. The plant produces small, round fruits that are typically yellow or red when ripe, with a sweet and aromatic flavor. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value and edible fruits, it is cultivated in some regions for both horticultural and culinary purposes.
